Two bakes cost the football association NOK 150,000: - That's how it is
Repeated rule violations became very costly for the Norwegian Football Association. They take self-criticism for the equipment failure.
02 Nov 2019, 12:45 by Viljam Brodahl
This summer, the Norwegian Football Association (NFF) was ordered to pay close to NOK 150,000 after a violation of equipment rules. It shows documents published by the International Football Association (FIFA) on its websites.
In May, Norway's U20 national team played in the World Cup finals in Poland. It was then the team on three occasions broke the rules.
First, the NFF received a warning after the opening match against Uruguay. The team used in connection with the settlement equipment with logos FIFA does not accept.
In the matches against New Zealand and Honduras, the rules were broken once again. It was after two episodes, where representatives of the Norwegian team were observed carrying on two bags, that the team again violated the rules of FIFA.
It was idrettspolitikk.no that first mentioned the case.

Norway's U20 national team played this summer during the World Cup finals in Poland.üì∑ VEGARD WIVESTAD GR√òTT / PILDBYR√ÖN NORWAY

Two violations
First case: Prior to the game against New Zealand, a bag of the brand ScanSports was brought into the stadium. Svein Graff, director of communications and society at NFF, says that it is common to use tape over logos to get around the problem. It was forgotten in this case.
Following the warning, FIFA then had to fine the team after repeated violations.
The NFF was fined 5,000 Swiss francs, corresponding to just under NOK 50,000.


How FIFA describes the rules violation in connection with the fight against New Zealand.üì∑ Screenshot / FIFA

- FIFA does this to protect its own sponsorship rights. FIFA has exclusive agreements. You just have to deal with that, says Truls D√¶hli, section manager for age-determined national teams in the NFF.

Second case: Prior to the last group game against Honduras, a player on the team wore a Nike shoe bag. The logo on the bag was larger than the size allowed. FIFA's rules state that the logo cannot be larger than 25 square centimeters.
After another break, FIFA had to work harder.
The NFF was fined 10,000 Swiss francs, corresponding to just under NOK 100,000.


How FIFA describes the rules violation in connection with the fight against Honduras.üì∑ Screenshot / FIFA

- Big fines
D√¶hli is aware that the team knew about the rules. Prior to the championship, FIFA informs which agreements apply and what can lead to breaches of the rules.
- There are big fines, but that's how it is. Mistakes can happen and there is no more to say about it, says D√¶hli.
In a response to FIFA, D√¶hli also complained to the federation after the rule breach ahead of the New Zealand match.
‚ÄúWe know the facts and we can only regret. The bag was brought by mistake. It is our responsibility and we can only apologize for the whole situation, ‚Äùthe documents state.
